Mate in 2: This puzzle is taken from the course 'Basic Chess Patterns' by John Neely. In this position both sides have exposed kings and Black can force checkmate in just two moves. Can you figure out how?

Opposition: This puzzle comes from a course 'Endgame Bootcamp' by IM John Bartholomew. The opposition, meaning when the kings faces off with one square in the middle, is a key endgame concept. It's beneficial to reach that position while it is the opponent who must make the next move. How can White take the opposition and then use it to help promote the pawn?
Anastasia's mate: Often, Anastasia's mate is preceded by a check with the knight, followed by a rook or queen sacrifice to open up a file. White to play!
Arabian mate: Often, Arabian mate is preceded by a sacrifice to open up the file/rank for the rook combined with a check with the knight to drive the king to a corner square. White to play!
Hook mate: Often, Hook mate is preceded by a rook check. White to play!
Vukovic's mate: Often, VukoviÄ‡'s mate is preceded by rook and/or knight checks. White to play!
Smothered mate: Often, Smothered mate is preceded by knight (double) checks followed by a queen sacrifice to force the opponent to trap his own king. White to play!
Suffocation mate: Sometimes, Suffocation mate is preceded by the same knight maneuver and queen sacrifice as in Smothered mate. White to play!
Corner mate: Sometimes, Corner mate is preceded by a sacrifice to remove a key defender. White to play!
Morphy's mate: Often, Morphy's mate is preceded by a check with a protected rook, followed by one or more discovered checks to eliminate important defenders of the king. White to play!
Pillsbury's mate: Often, Pillsbury's mate is preceded by a check with a protected rook, followed by rook sacrifice with double check. White to play!
Opera mate / Mayet's mate: Sometimes, Opera mate / Mayet's mate is preceded by a queen sacrifice on h2 or h7 (to open up the h-file), followed by a rook check. White to play!
